<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always">&nbsp;</H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">




<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 18pt"><B>Equity LifeStyle Properties, Inc.<BR>
Notes To Consolidated Financial Statements</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>Note 1 &#151; Organization of the Company and Basis of Presentation</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Equity LifeStyle Properties, Inc., a Maryland corporation, together with MHC Operating Limited
Partnership (the &#147;Operating Partnership&#148;) and other consolidated subsidiaries (&#147;Subsidiaries&#148;), is
referred to herein as the &#147;Company,&#148; &#147;ELS,&#148; &#147;we,&#148; &#147;us,&#148; and &#147;our.&#148; The Company is a fully
integrated owner and operator of lifestyle-oriented properties (&#147;Properties&#148;). The Company leases
individual developed areas (&#147;sites&#148;) with access to utilities for placement of factory built homes,
cottages, cabins or recreational vehicles (&#147;RVs&#148;). We believe that we have qualified for taxation
as a real estate investment trust (&#147;REIT&#148;) for U.S. federal income tax purposes since our taxable
year ended December&nbsp;31, 1993. We plan to continue to meet the requirements for taxation as a REIT.
Many of these requirements, however, are highly technical and complex. We cannot, therefore,
guarantee that we have qualified or will qualify in the future as a REIT. The determination that
we are a REIT requires an analysis of various factual matters that may not be totally within our
control and we cannot provide any assurance that the IRS will agree with our analysis. For
example, to qualify as a REIT, at least 95% of our gross income must come from sources that are
itemized in the REIT tax laws. We are also required to distribute to stockholders at least 90% of
our REIT taxable income computed without regard to our deduction for dividends paid and our net
capital gain. The fact that we hold our assets through the Operating Partnership and its
subsidiaries further complicates the application of the REIT requirements. Even a technical or
inadvertent mistake could jeopardize our REIT qualification. Furthermore, Congress and the IRS
might make changes to the tax laws and regulations, and the courts might issue new rulings that
make it more difficult, or impossible, for us to remain qualified as a REIT. We do not believe,
however, that any pending or proposed tax law changes would jeopardize our REIT qualification.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;If we fail to qualify as a REIT, we would be subject to U.S. federal income tax at regular
corporate rates. Also, unless the IRS granted us relief under certain statutory provisions, we
would remain disqualified as a REIT for four years following the year we first failed to qualify.
Even if the Company qualifies for taxation as a REIT, the Company is subject to certain foreign,
state and local taxes on its income and property and U.S. federal income and excise taxes on its
undistributed income.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The operations of the Company are conducted primarily through the Operating Partnership. The
Company contributed the proceeds from its initial public offering and subsequent offerings to the
Operating Partnership for a general partnership interest. In 2004, the general partnership
interest was contributed to MHC Trust, a private REIT subsidiary owned by the Company. The
financial results of the Operating Partnership and the Subsidiaries are consolidated in the
Company&#146;s consolidated financial statements. In addition, since certain activities, if performed
by the Company, may cause us to earn income which is not qualifying for the REIT gross income
tests, the Company has formed taxable REIT subsidiaries, as defined in the Code, to engage in such
activities.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Several Properties acquired are wholly-owned by taxable REIT subsidiaries of the Company. In
addition, Realty Systems, Inc. (&#147;RSI&#148;) is a wholly-owned taxable REIT subsidiary of the Company
that is engaged in the business of purchasing, selling and leasing homes that are located in
Properties owned and managed by the Company. RSI also provides brokerage services to customers at
such Properties. Typically, customers move from a Property but do not relocate their homes. RSI
may provide brokerage services, in competition with other local brokers, by seeking buyers for the
homes. RSI also leases inventory homes to prospective customers with the expectation that the
tenant eventually will purchase the home. Subsidiaries of RSI also lease from the Operating
Partnership certain real property within or adjacent to certain Properties consisting of golf
courses, pro shops, stores and restaurants.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The limited partners of the Operating Partnership (the &#147;Common OP Unitholders&#148;) receive an
allocation of net income that is based on their respective ownership percentage of the Operating
Partnership that is shown on the Consolidated Financial Statements as Minority Interests &#151; Common
OP Units. As of December&nbsp;31, 2007, the Minority Interests &#151; Common OP Units represented 5,836,043
units of limited partnership interest (&#147;OP Units&#148;) which are convertible into an equivalent number
of shares of the Company&#146;s common stock. The issuance of additional shares of common stock or
common OP Units changes the respective ownership of the Operating Partnership for both the Minority
Interests and the Company.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio -->F-10<!-- /Folio -->
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always">&nbsp;</H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 18pt"><B>Equity LifeStyle Properties, Inc.<BR>
Notes To Consolidated Financial Statements</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>Note 2 &#151; Summary of Significant Accounting Policies</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 2%"><I>(a)&nbsp;Basis of Consolidation</I>

</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 2%">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company consolidates its majority-owned subsidiaries in which it has the ability to
control the operations of the subsidiaries and all variable interest entities with respect to
which the Company is the primary beneficiary. The Company also consolidates entities in which it
has a controlling direct or indirect voting interest. All inter-company transactions have been
eliminated in consolidation. The Company&#146;s acquisitions were all accounted for as purchases in
accordance with Statement of Financial Accounting Standards No.&nbsp;141, &#147;Business Combinations&#148;
(&#147;SFAS No.&nbsp;141&#148;).
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 2%">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company has applied the Financial Accounting Standards Board (&#147;FASB&#148;) issued
Interpretation No.&nbsp;46R, &#147;Consolidation of Variable Interest Entities&#148; (&#147;FIN 46R&#148;) &#151; an
interpretation of ARB 51. The objective of FIN 46R is to provide guidance on how to identify a
variable interest entity (&#147;VIE&#148;) and determine when the assets, liabilities, non-controlling
interests, and results of operations of a VIE need to be included in a company&#146;s consolidated
financial statements. A company that holds variable interests in an entity will need to
consolidate such entity if the company absorbs a majority of the entity&#146;s expected losses or
receives a majority of the entity&#146;s expected residual returns if they occur, or both (i.e., the
primary beneficiary). The Company has also applied Emerging Issues Task Force 04-5 &#151; Accounting
for investments in limited partnerships when the investor is the sole general partner and the
limited partners have certain rights (&#147;EITF 04-5&#148;) which determines whether a general partner or
the general partners as a group controls a limited partnership or similar entity and therefore
should consolidate the entity. The Company will apply FIN 46R and EITF 04-5 to all types of
entity ownership (general and limited partnerships and corporate interests).
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 2%">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company applies the equity method of accounting to entities in which the Company does
not have a controlling direct or indirect voting interest or is not considered the primary
beneficiary, but can exercise influence over the entity with respect to its operations and major
decisions. The cost method is applied when (i)&nbsp;the investment is minimal (typically less than
5%) and (ii)&nbsp;the Company&#146;s investment is passive.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 2%">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;As of December&nbsp;31, 2007, the Bar Harbor joint venture has been consolidated with the
operations of the Company as the Company has determined that as of December&nbsp;31, 2007 we are the
primary beneficiary by applying the standards of FIN 46R.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 2%"><I>(b)&nbsp;Use of Estimates</I>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 2%">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The preparation of financial statements in conformity with accounting principles generally
accepted in the United States requires management to make estimates and assumptions that affect
the reported amounts of assets and liabilities and disclosure of contingent assets and
liabilities at the date of the financial statements and the reported amounts of revenues and
expenses during the reporting period. Actual results could differ from those estimates.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 2%">(<I>c) Markets</I>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 2%">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We manage all our operations on a property-by-property basis. Since each Property has
similar economic and operational characteristics, the Company has one reportable segment, which
is the operation of land lease Properties. The distribution of the Properties throughout the
United States reflects our belief that geographic diversification helps insulate the portfolio
from regional economic influences. We intend to target new acquisitions in or near markets where
the Properties are located and will also consider acquisitions of Properties outside such
markets.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 2%"><I>(d)&nbsp;Inventory</I>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 2%">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Inventory consists of new and used Site Set homes and is stated at the lower of cost or
market after consideration of the N.A.D.A. Manufactured Housing Appraisal Guide and the current
market value of each home included in the home inventory. Inventory sales revenues and resale
revenues are recognized when the home sale is closed. Inventory is recorded net of an inventory
reserve as of December&nbsp;31, 2007 and December&nbsp;31, 2006 of $0.8&nbsp;million and $0.6&nbsp;million,
respectively. The expense for the inventory reserve is included in the cost of home sales in our
Consolidated Statements of Operations. Resale revenues are stated net of commissions paid to
employees of $0.8&nbsp;million and $1.2&nbsp;million for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2007 and 2006,
respectively. (See Note 7 in the Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements contained in this
Form 10-K)
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio -->F-11<!-- /Folio -->
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always">&nbsp;</H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 18pt"><B>Equity LifeStyle Properties, Inc.<BR>
Notes To Consolidated Financial Statements</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>Note 2 &#151; Summary of Significant Accounting Policies (continued)</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 2%"><I>(e)&nbsp;Real Estate</I>

</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 2%">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In accordance with SFAS No.&nbsp;141, we allocate the purchase price of Properties we acquire to
net tangible and identified intangible assets acquired based on their fair values. In making
estimates of fair values for purposes of allocating purchase price, we utilize a number of
sources, including independent appraisals that may be available in connection with the
acquisition or financing of the respective Property and other market data. We also consider
information obtained about each Property as a result of our due diligence, marketing and leasing
activities in estimating the fair value of the tangible and intangible assets acquired.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 2%">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Real estate is recorded at cost less accumulated depreciation. Depreciation is computed on
the straight-line basis over the estimated useful lives of the assets. We use a 30-year estimated
life for buildings acquired and structural and land improvements, a ten-to-fifteen-year estimated
life for building upgrades and a three-to-seven-year estimated life for furniture, fixtures and
equipment. The values of above-and below-market leases are amortized and recorded as either an
increase (in the case of below market-leases) or a decrease (in the case of above-market leases)
to rental income over the remaining term of the associated lease. The value associated with
in-place leases is amortized over the expected term, which includes an estimated probability of
lease renewal. Expenditures for ordinary maintenance and repairs are expensed to operations as
incurred, and significant renovations and improvements that improve the asset and extend the
useful life of the asset are capitalized and then expensed over the asset&#146;s estimated useful
life.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 2%">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We periodically evaluate our long-lived assets, including our investments in real estate,
for impairment indicators. Our judgments regarding the existence of impairment indicators are
based on factors such as operational performance, market conditions and legal factors. Future
events could occur which would cause us to conclude that impairment indicators exist and an
impairment loss is warranted.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 2%">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;For Properties to be disposed of, an impairment loss is recognized when the fair value of
the Property, less the estimated cost to sell, is less than the carrying amount of the Property
measured at the time the Company has a commitment to sell the Property and/or is actively
marketing the Property for sale. A Property to be disposed of is reported at the lower of its
carrying amount or its estimated fair value, less costs to sell. Subsequent to the date that a
Property is held for disposition, depreciation expense is not recorded. The Company accounts for
its Properties held for disposition in accordance with Statement of Financial Accounting
Standards No.&nbsp;144 &#147;Accounting for the Impairment or Disposal of Long-Lived Assets&#148; (&#147;SFAS No.
144&#148;). Accordingly, the results of operations for all assets sold or held for sale after January
1, 2003 have been classified as discontinued operations in all periods presented.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 2%"><I>(f)&nbsp;Cash and Cash Equivalents</I>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 2%">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We consider all demand and money market accounts and certificates of deposit with a maturity
date, when purchased, of three months or less to be cash equivalents.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 2%"><I>(g)&nbsp;Notes Receivable</I>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 2%">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Notes receivable generally are stated at their outstanding unpaid principal balances net of
any deferred fees or costs on originated loans, or unamortized discounts or premiums net of a valuation allowance.
Interest income is accrued on the unpaid principal balance. Discounts or premiums are amortized
to income using the interest method. In certain cases we finance the sales of homes to our
customers (referred to as &#147;Chattel Loans&#148;) which loans are secured by the homes. The valuation
allowance for the Chattel Loans is calculated based on a comparison of the outstanding principal
balance of each note compared to the N.A.D.A. value and the current market value of the
underlying manufactured home collateral.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio -->F-12<!-- /Folio -->
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always">&nbsp;</H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 18pt"><B>Equity LifeStyle Properties, Inc.<BR>
Notes To Consolidated Financial Statements</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>Note 2 &#151; Summary of Significant Accounting Policies (continued)</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 2%"><I>(h)&nbsp;Investments in Joint Ventures</I>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 2%">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Investments in joint ventures in which the Company does not have a controlling direct or
indirect voting interest, but can exercise significant influence over the entity with respect to
its operations and major decisions, are accounted for using the equity method of accounting
whereby the cost of an investment is adjusted for the Company&#146;s share of the equity in net income
or loss from the date of acquisition and reduced by distributions received. The income or loss
of each entity is allocated in accordance with the provisions of the applicable operating
agreements. The allocation provisions in these agreements may differ from the ownership
interests held by each investor. Differences between the carrying amount of the Company&#146;s
investment in the respective entities and the Company&#146;s share of the underlying equity of such
unconsolidated entities are amortized over the respective lives of the underlying assets, as
applicable.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 2%"><I>(i)&nbsp;Income from Other Investments, net</I>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 2%">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Income from other investments, net includes revenue relating to the Company&#146;s ground leases
with Privileged Access L.P. (&#147;Privileged Access&#148;) of $20.6&nbsp;million and $17.9&nbsp;million for the
years ended December&nbsp;31, 2007 and 2006, respectively. Privileged Access leases approximately
24,100 membership campground sites at 81 of the Company&#146;s Properties. The leases are subject to
annual CPI increases and have a remaining term of approximately 12&nbsp;years (see Note 12 in the
Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements contained in this Form 10-K). In 2007, income from
other investments, net also includes a one-time gain of approximately $1.1&nbsp;million earned in
connection with a 2005 defeasance transaction.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 2%"><I>(j)&nbsp;Insurance Claims</I>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 2%">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Properties are covered against fire, flood, property damage, earthquake, windstorm and
business interruption by insurance policies containing various deductible requirements and
coverage limits. Recoverable costs are classified in other assets as incurred. Insurance
proceeds are applied against the asset when received. Recoverable costs relating to capital
items are treated in accordance with the Company&#146;s capitalization policy. The book value of the
original capital item is written off once the value of the impaired asset has been determined.
Insurance proceeds relating to the capital costs are recorded as income in the period they are
received.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 2%">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Approximately 70 Florida Properties suffered damage from the four hurricanes that struck the
state during August and September&nbsp;2004. As of February&nbsp;19, 2008, the Company estimates its total
claim to be $21.8&nbsp;million, of which approximately $21.5&nbsp;million of claims, including business
interruption, have been submitted to its insurance companies for reimbursement. Through December
31, 2007, the Company has made total expenditures of approximately $17.4&nbsp;million and expects to
incur additional expenditures to complete the work necessary to restore the Properties to their
pre-hurricanes condition. The Company has reserved approximately $2.0&nbsp;million related to these
expenditures ($0.7&nbsp;million in 2005 and $1.3&nbsp;million in 2004). Approximately $6.8&nbsp;million of
these expenditures have been capitalized per the Company&#146;s capitalization policy through December
31, 2007.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 2%">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company has received proceeds from insurance carriers of approximately $7.9&nbsp;million
through December&nbsp;31, 2007. The proceeds were accounted for in accordance with the Statement of
Financial Accounting Standards No.5, &#147;Accounting for Contingencies&#148; (&#147;SFAS No.&nbsp;5&#148;).
Approximately $0.6&nbsp;million has been recognized as a gain on insurance recovery, which is net of
approximately $0.2&nbsp;million of contingent legal fees and included in income from other
investments, net, as of December&nbsp;31, 2007. The receivable from insurance providers included in
other assets of approximately $1.5&nbsp;million as of December&nbsp;31, 2006, was collected in full during
2007.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 2%">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On June&nbsp;22, 2007, the Company filed a lawsuit related to some of the unpaid claims against
certain insurance carriers and its insurance broker. See Note 18 in the Notes to Consolidated
Financial Statements contained in this Form 10-K for further discussion of this lawsuit
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 2%"><I>(k)&nbsp;Fair Value of Financial Instruments</I>

</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 2%">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company&#146;s financial instruments include short-term investments, notes receivable,
accounts receivable, accounts payable, other accrued expenses, and mortgage notes payable. The
fair values of all financial instruments, including notes receivable, were not materially
different from their carrying values at December&nbsp;31, 2007 and 2006.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio -->F-13<!-- /Folio -->
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always">&nbsp;</H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 18pt"><B>Equity LifeStyle Properties, Inc.<BR>
Notes To Consolidated Financial Statements</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>Note 2 &#151; Summary of Significant Accounting Policies (continued)</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 2%"><I>(l)&nbsp;Deferred Financing Costs, net</I>

</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 2%">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Deferred financing costs, net include fees and costs incurred to obtain long-term
financing. The costs are being amortized over the terms of the respective loans on a level
yield basis. Unamortized deferred financing fees are written-off when debt is retired before
the maturity date. Upon amendment of the lines of credit, unamortized deferred financing fees
are accounted for in accordance with, Emerging Issues Task Force No.&nbsp;98-14, &#147;Debtor&#146;s Accounting
for Changes in Line-of-Credit or Revolving-Debt Arrangements&#148; (&#147;EITF No.&nbsp;98-14&#148;). Accumulated
amortization for such costs was $10.3&nbsp;million and $9.4&nbsp;million at December&nbsp;31, 2007 and 2006,
respectively.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 2%"><I>(m)&nbsp;Revenue Recognition</I>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 2%">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company accounts for leases with its customers as operating leases. Rental income is
recognized over the term of the respective lease or the length of a customer&#146;s stay, the
majority of which are for a term of not greater than one year. We will reserve for receivables
when we believe the ultimate collection is less than probable. Our provision for uncollectible
rents receivable was approximately $1.2&nbsp;million and $0.9&nbsp;million as of December&nbsp;31, 2007 and
December&nbsp;31, 2006, respectively. Income from home sales is recognized when the earnings process
is complete. The earnings process is complete when the home has been delivered; the purchaser
has accepted the home and title has transferred.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 2%"><I>(n)&nbsp;Minority Interests</I>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 2%">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Net income is allocated to Common OP Unitholders based on their respective ownership
percentage of the Operating Partnership. Such ownership percentage is calculated by dividing
the number of common OP Units held by the Common OP Unitholders (5,836,043 and 6,090,068 at
December&nbsp;31, 2007 and 2006, respectively) by the total OP Units held by the Common OP
Unitholders and the Company. Issuance of additional shares of common stock or common OP Units
changes the percentage ownership of both the Minority Interests and the Company. Due in part to
the exchange rights (which provide for the conversion of common OP Units into shares of common
stock on a one-for-one basis), such transactions and the proceeds there from are treated as
capital transactions and result in an allocation between stockholders&#146; equity and Minority
Interests to account for the change in the respective percentage ownership of the underlying
equity of the Operating Partnership.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 2%"><I>(o)&nbsp;Income Taxes</I>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 2%">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Due to the structure of the Company as a REIT, the results of operations contain no
provision for U.S. federal income taxes for the REIT. However, the Company may be subject to
certain foreign, state and local income, excise or franchise taxes. The Company paid federal,
foreign, state and local taxes of approximately $369,000 and $261,000 during the years ended
December&nbsp;31, 2007 and 2006, respectively, which includes taxes payable from activities managed
through taxable REIT subsidiaries. As of December&nbsp;31, 2007, net investment in real estate and
notes receivable had a U.S. federal tax basis of approximately $1.5&nbsp;billion and $11.1&nbsp;million,
respectively.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 2%">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company adopted the provisions of Financial Standards Accounting Board Interpretation
No.&nbsp;48 &#147;Accounting for Uncertainty in Income Taxes&#148; (&#147;FIN 48&#148;) an interpretation of FASB
Statement No.&nbsp;109 &#147;Accounting for Income Taxes,&#148; on January&nbsp;1, 2007. The adoption of FIN 48
resulted in no impact to the Company&#146;s consolidated financial statements. The Company or one of
its subsidiaries files income tax returns in the U.S. federal jurisdiction, various U.S. state
jurisdictions and Canada. With few exceptions, the Company is no longer subject to U.S.
federal, state and local, or non-U.S. income tax examinations by tax authorities for years
before 2004.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 2%"><I>(p)&nbsp;Derivative Instruments and Hedging Activities</I>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 2%">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company recognizes all derivatives on the balance sheet at fair value. Derivatives
that are not hedges must be adjusted to fair value through income. If the derivative is a
hedge, depending on the nature of the hedge, changes in the fair value of derivatives will
either be offset against the change in fair value of the hedged assets, liabilities or firm
commitments through earnings or recognized in other comprehensive income until the hedged item
is recognized in earnings.
</DIV>



<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio -->F-14<!-- /Folio -->
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always">&nbsp;</H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">




<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 18pt"><B>Equity LifeStyle Properties, Inc.<BR>
Notes To Consolidated Financial Statements</B>
</DIV>
<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>Note 2 &#151; Summary of Significant Accounting Policies (continued)</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 2%"><I>(q)&nbsp;Stock Compensation</I>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 2%">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company adopted the fair-value-based method of accounting for share-based payments
effective January&nbsp;1, 2003 using the modified prospective method described in FASB Statement No.
148, &#147;Accounting for Stock-Based Compensation-Transition and Disclosure&#148; (&#147;SFAS No.&nbsp;148&#148;). The
Company adopted Statement of Financial Accounting Standards No.&nbsp;123(R), &#147;Share Based Payment&#148;
(&#147;SFAS 123(R)&#148;) on July&nbsp;1, 2005, which did not have a material impact on the Company&#146;s results
of operations or its financial position. The Company uses the Black-Scholes-Merton formula to
estimate the value of stock options granted to employees (see Note 13 in the Notes to
Consolidated Financial Statements contained in this Form 10-K).
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 2%"><I>(r)&nbsp;Recent Accounting Pronouncements</I>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 2%">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In December&nbsp;2007, the Financial Accounting Standards Board (&#147;FASB&#148;) issued Statement of
Financial Accounting Standards No.&nbsp;160, &#147;Non-controlling Interests in Consolidated Financial
Statements&#148; (&#147;SFAS No.&nbsp;160&#148;), an amendment of Accounting Research Bulletin No.&nbsp;51. The
Statement seeks to improve uniformity and transparency in reporting of the net income
attributable to non-controlling interests in the consolidated financial statements of the
reporting entity. The statement requires, among other provisions, the disclosure, clear
labeling and presentation of non-controlling interests in the Consolidated Balance Sheet and
Consolidated Income Statement. SFAS No.&nbsp;160 is effective January&nbsp;1, 2009 with early adoption
prohibited. The Company does not expect the adoption of SFAS No.&nbsp;160 will have a material
effect on the financial position of the Company.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 2%">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In December&nbsp;2007, the FASB issued Statement of Financial Accounting Standard No.&nbsp;141R,
&#147;Business Combinations,&#148; (&#147;SFAS No.&nbsp;141R&#148;). SFAS No.&nbsp;141R replaces FASB Statement No.&nbsp;141 but
retains the fundamental requirements in SFAS No.&nbsp;141 that the acquisition method of accounting
(also known as the purchase method) be used for all business combinations and for an acquirer to
be identified for each business combination. SFAS No.&nbsp;141R also establishes principles and
requirements for how the acquirer: (a)&nbsp;recognizes and measures in its financial statements the
identifiable assets acquired, the liabilities assumed, and any non-controlling interest in the
acquired entity; (b)&nbsp;improves the completeness of the information reported about a business
combination by changing the requirements for recognizing assets acquired and liabilities assumed
arising from contingencies; (c)&nbsp;recognizes and measures the goodwill acquired in the business
combination or a gain from a bargain purchase; and (d)&nbsp;determines what information to disclose
to enable users of the financial statements to evaluate the nature and financial effects of the
business combination. SFAS No.&nbsp;141R replaces, with limited exceptions as specified in the
Statement, the cost allocation process in SFAS No.&nbsp;141 with a fair value based allocation
process. SFAS No.&nbsp;141R applies prospectively to business combinations for which the acquisition
date is on or after the beginning of the first annual reporting period beginning on or after
December&nbsp;15, 2008. Early application is not permitted. The Company has not yet determined the
impact, if any, that SFAS No.&nbsp;141R will have on its consolidated financial statements.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 2%">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In February&nbsp;2007, the FASB issued Statement of Financial Accounting Standards No.&nbsp;159, &#147;The
Fair Value Option for Financial Assets and Financial Liabilities&#148; (&#147;SFAS No.&nbsp;159&#148;). SFAS No.
159 permits companies to choose to measure many financial instruments and certain other items at
fair value. The objective is to improve financial reporting by providing companies with the
opportunity to mitigate volatility in reported earnings caused by measuring related assets and
liabilities differently without having to apply complex hedge accounting provisions. SFAS No.
159 is effective for fiscal years beginning after November&nbsp;15, 2007. Companies are not allowed to
adopt SFAS No.&nbsp;159 on a retrospective basis unless they choose early adoption. The adoption of
SFAS No.&nbsp;159 is optional and the Company plans to evaluate the potential adoption in 2008.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 2%">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In September&nbsp;2006, the FASB issued Statement of Financial Accounting Standards No.&nbsp;157,
&#147;Fair Value Measurements&#148; (&#147;SFAS No.&nbsp;157&#148;), which defines fair value, establishes a framework
for measuring fair value in generally accepted accounting principles, and expands disclosures
about fair value measurements. SFAS No.&nbsp;157 does not require any new fair value measurements,
but provides guidance on how to measure fair value by providing a fair value hierarchy used to
classify the source of the information. This statement is effective for the Company beginning
January&nbsp;1, 2008. The Company does not expect the adoption of SFAS No.&nbsp;157 will have a material
effect on its financial statements.
</DIV>


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio -->F-15<!-- /Folio -->
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always">&nbsp;</H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 18pt"><B>Equity LifeStyle Properties, Inc.<BR>
Notes To Consolidated Financial Statements</B>
</DIV>
<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>Note 2 &#151; Summary of Significant Accounting Policies (continued)</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 2%">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In June&nbsp;2006, FASB issued Interpretation No.&nbsp;48, &#147;Accounting for Uncertainty in Income
Taxes, an interpretation of FAS 109, Accounting for Income Taxes&#148; (&#147;FIN 48&#148;), to create a single
model to address accounting for uncertainty in
tax positions. FIN 48 clarifies the accounting for income taxes by prescribing a minimum
recognition threshold a tax position is required to meet before being recognized in the
financial statements. FIN 48 also provides guidance on derecognition, measurement,
classification, interest and penalties, accounting in interim periods, disclosure and
transition. FIN 48 is effective for fiscal years beginning after December&nbsp;15, 2006. The
Company adopted FIN 48 on January&nbsp;1, 2007. The adoption of FIN 48 resulted in no impact to the
Company&#146;s consolidated financial statements. The Company or one of its subsidiaries files
income tax returns in the U.S. federal jurisdiction, various U.S. state jurisdictions and
Canada. With few exceptions, the Company is no longer subject to U.S. federal, state and local,
or non-U.S. income tax examinations by tax authorities for years before 2004.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt; margin-left: 2%"><I>(s)&nbsp;Reclassifications</I>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt; margin-left: 2%">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Certain 2006 and 2005 amounts have been reclassified to conform to the 2007 presentation.
This reclassification had no material effect on the consolidated balance sheets or statement of
operations of the Company.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio -->F-16<!-- /Folio -->
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always">&nbsp;</H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 18pt"><B>Equity LifeStyle Properties, Inc.<BR>
Notes To Consolidated Financial Statements</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>Note 3 &#151; Earnings Per Common Share</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Earnings per common share are based on the weighted average number of common shares
outstanding during each year. Statement of Financial Accounting Standards No.&nbsp;128, &#147;Earnings Per
Share&#148; (&#147;SFAS No.&nbsp;128&#148;) defines the calculation of basic and fully diluted earnings per share.
Basic and fully diluted earnings per share are based on the weighted average shares outstanding
during each year and basic earnings per share exclude any dilutive effects of options, warrants and
convertible securities. The conversion of OP Units has been excluded from the basic earnings per
share calculation. The conversion of an OP Unit to a share of common stock has no effect on
earnings per common share.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The following table sets forth the computation of basic and diluted earnings per share for the
years ended December&nbsp;31, 2007, 2006 and 2005 (amounts in thousands):
</DIV>

<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always">&nbsp;</H5><P>
<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">


<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 18pt"><B>Equity LifeStyle Properties, Inc.<BR>
Notes To Consolidated Financial Statements</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>Note 4 &#151; Common Stock and Other Equity Related Transactions</B>

</DIV>

50,000,000 to 100,000,000.
</DIV>

6,207,471 outstanding at December&nbsp;31, 2007, 2006 and 2005, respectively):

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;As of December&nbsp;31, 2007 and 2006, the Company&#146;s percentage ownership of the Operating
Partnership was approximately 80.6% and 79.7%, respectively. The remaining approximately 19.4% and
20.3%, respectively, was owned by the Common OP Unitholders.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On March&nbsp;24, 2005, the Operating Partnership issued $25&nbsp;million of 8.0625% Series&nbsp;D Cumulative
Redeemable Perpetual Preference Units (the &#147;Series&nbsp;D 8% Units&#148;), to institutional investors. The
Series&nbsp;D 8% Units are non-callable for five years. In addition, the Operating Partnership had an
existing $125&nbsp;million of 9.0% Series&nbsp;D Cumulative Redeemable Perpetual Preference Units (the
&#147;Series&nbsp;D 9% Units&#148;) outstanding that were callable by the Company as of September&nbsp;2004. In
connection with the new issue, the Operating Partnership agreed to extend the non-call provision of
the Series&nbsp;D 9% Units to be coterminous with the new issue, and the institutional investors holding
the Series&nbsp;D 9% Units agreed to lower the rate on such units to 8.0625%. All of the units have no
stated maturity or mandatory redemption. Net proceeds from the offering were used to pay down
amounts outstanding under the Company&#146;s lines of credit.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On June&nbsp;30, 2005, the Operating Partnership issued $50&nbsp;million of 7.95% Series&nbsp;F Cumulative
Redeemable Perpetual Preference Units (the &#147;Series&nbsp;F Units&#148;), to institutional investors. The
Series&nbsp;F Units are non-callable for five years and have no stated maturity or mandatory redemption.
Net proceeds from the offering were used to pay down amounts outstanding under the Company&#146;s lines
of credit.
</DIV>

stockholders and Minority Interests since January&nbsp;1, 2005:

<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always">&nbsp;</H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">


<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 18pt"><B>Equity LifeStyle Properties, Inc.<BR>
Notes To Consolidated Financial Statements</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>Note 4 &#151; Common Stock and Other Equity Related Transactions (continued)</B>

</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company adopted, the 1997 Non-Qualified Employee Stock Purchase Plan (&#147;ESPP&#148;). Pursuant
to the ESPP in July&nbsp;1997 as amended on May&nbsp;3, 2007, certain employees and directors of the Company
may each annually acquire up to $250,000 of common stock of the Company. The aggregate number of
shares of common stock available under the ESPP shall not exceed 1,000,000, subject to adjustment
by the Company&#146;s Board of Directors. The common stock may be purchased monthly at a price equal to
85% of the lesser of: (a)&nbsp;the closing price for a share of common stock on the last day of the
offering period; and (b)&nbsp;the closing price for a share of common stock on the first day of the
offering period. Shares of common stock issued through the ESPP for the years ended December&nbsp;31,
2007 and 2006 were 21,677 and 22,620, respectively.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Land improvements consist primarily of improvements such as grading, landscaping and
infrastructure items such as streets, sidewalks or water mains. Depreciable property consists of
permanent buildings in the Properties such as clubhouses, laundry facilities, maintenance storage
facilities, and furniture, fixtures and equipment.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">All acquisitions have been accounted for utilizing the purchase method of accounting and,
accordingly, the results of operations of acquired assets are included in the statements of
operations from the dates of acquisition. Certain purchase price adjustments may be made within
one year following the acquisitions. We acquired all of these Properties from unaffiliated third
parties. During the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2007, 2006 and 2005, the Company acquired the
following Properties (amounts in millions, except site information):
</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt">
<TR>
    <TD width="3%"></TD>
    <TD width="1%"></TD>
    <TD width="96"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD nowrap align="left">(a)</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>Purchased remaining interest in the Mezzanine Portfolio in which we had initially
invested approximately $30.0&nbsp;million to acquire preferred equity interests during the first
quarter of 2004. The purchase price of $105.0&nbsp;million included our existing investment of
$32.2&nbsp;million and our general partner investment of $1.4&nbsp;million. Net working capital
acquired included $3.2&nbsp;million of rents received in advance and $0.4&nbsp;million in other net
payables. In connection with this acquisition we purchased $1.9&nbsp;million of inventory. The
acquisition was funded by new debt financing of $47.1&nbsp;million and assumed debt of
approximately $25.9&nbsp;million.</TD>
</TR>

<TR style="font-size: 3pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD nowrap align="left">(b)</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>The purchase price includes certain personal property acquired from Privileged Access
located throughout the Thousand Trails Portfolio. The Company leased back these Properties
to Privileged Access.</TD>
</TR>

<TR style="font-size: 3pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD nowrap align="left">(c)</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>The portfolio was acquired in exchange for $5.0&nbsp;million in cash, and two Properties
previously held for sale, located in Indiana. The Company provided short-term seller
financing of $3.4&nbsp;million at the time of closing which was repaid in full on August&nbsp;21,
2006. Net working capital acquired included $0.6&nbsp;million of rents received in advance.
The Company leased all 1,594 sites in the portfolio to Privileged Access.</TD>
</TR>

<TR style="font-size: 3pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD nowrap align="left">(d)</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>Net working capital acquired included approximately $0.2&nbsp;million of rents received in
advance.</TD>
</TR>

<TR style="font-size: 3pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD nowrap align="left">(e)</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>Purchased remaining 75% interest in four Diversified joint venture Properties in which
we had an existing 25% joint venture ownership interest of $0.6&nbsp;million. Net working
capital acquired included $1.2&nbsp;million of rents received in advance and $0.6&nbsp;million of
escrow deposits. A portion of the purchase price was funded by assumed debt of
approximately $12.8&nbsp;million.</TD>
</TR>

<TR style="font-size: 3pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD nowrap align="left">(f)</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>The Company leased all 3,962 sites in the portfolio to Privileged Access.</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>Note 5 &#151; Investment in Real Estate (continued)</B>

</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We actively seek to acquire additional Properties and currently are engaged in negotiations
relating to the possible acquisition of a number of Properties. At any time these negotiations are
at varying stages which may include contracts to acquire certain Properties which are subject to
satisfactory completion of our due diligence review.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;As of December&nbsp;31, 2007, the Company has two Properties designated as held for disposition
pursuant to SFAS No.&nbsp;144. The Company determined that these Properties no longer met its
investment criteria. As such, the results from operations of these two Properties, one Property
sold in November&nbsp;2007, one Property sold in July&nbsp;2007, one Property sold in January&nbsp;2007, and two
Properties sold in April&nbsp;2006 are classified as income from discontinued operations. The Properties
classified as held for disposition as of December&nbsp;31, 2007 are listed in the table below.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>Note 6 &#151; Investment in Joint Ventures</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;During the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2007, the Company invested approximately $2.7&nbsp;million in
developing one of the Bar Harbor joint venture Properties, which resulted in an increase of the
Company&#146;s ownership interest per the joint venture agreement. As of December&nbsp;31, 2007, the Bar
Harbor joint venture has been consolidated with the operations of the Company as the Company has
determined that as of December&nbsp;31, 2007 we are the primary beneficiary by applying the standards of
FIN 46R. This consolidation has decreased the Company&#146;s investment in joint venture approximately
$11.1&nbsp;million, with an offsetting increase in investment in real estate.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;During the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2007, the Company received approximately $5.2&nbsp;million in
distributions from our joint ventures. $5.1&nbsp;million of these distributions were classified as
return on capital and were included in operating activities. The remaining distributions of
approximately $0.1&nbsp;million were classified as a return of capital and were included in investing
activities and were related to refinancings at three of our joint venture Properties.
Approximately $2.5&nbsp;million of the distributions received exceeded the Company&#146;s basis in its joint
venture and as such were recorded in income from unconsolidated joint ventures.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;During the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2006, the Company invested approximately $1.1&nbsp;million in
five joint ventures owning five Properties located in Florida, Massachusetts, Maine and two in
Virginia. The Company also invested approximately $1.6&nbsp;million in developing one of the Bar Harbor
joint venture Properties, which resulted in an increase of the Company&#146;s ownership interest per the
joint venture agreement.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;During the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2006, the Company received approximately $5.1&nbsp;million in
distributions from our joint ventures. $3.5&nbsp;million of these distributions were classified as
return on capital and were included in operating activities. The remaining distributions of
approximately $1.6&nbsp;million were classified as a return of capital and were included in investing
activities. The return of capital distributions related to our sale of the Property owned by
Indian Wells joint venture and the sale of our interest in the Blazing Star joint venture.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;During the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2005, the Company invested approximately $7.0&nbsp;million for a
50% preferred joint venture interest in three Properties located near Bar Harbor, Maine. The
Company also invested approximately $0.6&nbsp;million for a 40% interest in a Texas Property owned by a
joint venture controlled by Diversified Investments, Inc (&#147;Diversified&#148;).
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;During the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2005, the Company received approximately $11.3&nbsp;million in
distributions from our joint ventures. $5.8&nbsp;million of these distributions were classified as
return on capital and were included in operating activities. The remaining distributions of
approximately $5.5&nbsp;million were classified as a return of capital, were included in investing
</DIV>


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio -->F-22<!-- /Folio -->
</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt">

    <TD width="3%"></TD>

</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD nowrap align="left">(1)</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>Includes 860 and 915 new units for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2007 and 2006,
respectively.</TD>
</TR>

<TR style="font-size: 3pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD nowrap align="left">(2)</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>Includes 978 and 1,023 used units for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2007 and 2006,
respectively.</TD>
</TR>

<TR style="font-size: 3pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD nowrap align="left">(3)</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>Includes $0.3&nbsp;million and $0.8&nbsp;million in discontinued operations for the years ended
December&nbsp;31, 2007 and 2006, respectively.</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>



<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Included in the new and used manufactured homes inventory are approximately $20.5&nbsp;million of
homes that are being rented, generally on an annual basis, as of December&nbsp;31, 2007.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>Note 8 &#151; Notes Receivable</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;As of December&nbsp;31, 2007 and December&nbsp;31, 2006, the Company had approximately $11.0&nbsp;million and
$22.0&nbsp;million in notes receivable, respectively. As of December&nbsp;31, 2007 and 2006, the Company has
approximately $10.6&nbsp;million and $9.4&nbsp;million, respectively, in Chattel Loans receivable, which
yield interest at a per annum average rate of approximately 9.1%, have an average term and
amortization of 5 to 15&nbsp;years, require monthly principal and interest payments and are
collateralized by homes at certain of the Properties. These notes are recorded net of allowances
of $160,000 and $110,000 as of December&nbsp;31, 2007 and December&nbsp;31, 2006, respectively.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;As of December&nbsp;31, 2007 and 2006, the Company had approximately $0.4&nbsp;million in notes which
bear interest at a per annum rate of prime plus 0.5% and mature on December&nbsp;31, 2011. The notes
are collateralized with a combination of common OP Units and partnership interests in certain joint
ventures.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;As of December&nbsp;31, 2006, we had a note receivable from Privileged Access of approximately
$12.3&nbsp;million, which was repaid in full during 2007.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio -->F-24<!-- /Folio -->
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always">&nbsp;</H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 18pt"><B>Equity LifeStyle Properties, Inc.<BR>
Notes To Consolidated Financial Statements</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>Note 9 &#151; Long-Term Borrowings</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt"><B>Secured Debt</B>

</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;As of December&nbsp;31, 2007 and December&nbsp;31, 2006, the Company had outstanding mortgage
indebtedness on Properties held for long term of approximately $1,542&nbsp;million and $1,569&nbsp;million,
respectively, and approximately $14&nbsp;million and $17&nbsp;million of mortgage indebtedness as of December
31, 2007 and December&nbsp;31, 2006, respectively on Properties held for sale. The weighted average
interest rate on this mortgage indebtedness for the both years ended December&nbsp;31, 2007 and 2006,
was approximately 6.1% per annum. The debt bears interest at rates of 4.3% to 10.0% per annum and
matures on various dates ranging from 2008 to 2016. Included in our debt balance are three capital
leases with an imputed interest rate of 13.1% per annum. The debt encumbered a total of 164 of
the Company&#146;s Properties for both years ending December&nbsp;31, 2007 and December&nbsp;31, 2006, and the
carrying value of such Properties was approximately $1,784&nbsp;million and $1,746&nbsp;million,
respectively, as of such dates.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>Financing, Refinancing and Early Debt Retirement</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In connection with the acquisition of Mesa Verde, during the first quarter of 2007, the
Company assumed $3.5&nbsp;million in mortgage debt bearing interest at 4.94% per annum and maturing in
May&nbsp;2008. In connection with the acquisition of Winter Garden, during the second quarter of 2007,
the Company assumed $4.0&nbsp;million in mortgage debt bearing interest at 4.3% per annum and maturing
in September&nbsp;2008. In connection with the acquisition of Tuxbury, the Company financed $1.2
million of the purchase price from the seller.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;During the first quarter of 2007, the Company repaid approximately $1.9&nbsp;million in mortgage
debt financing in connection with the sale of Lazy Lakes. Refer to Note 5  &#151; Investment in Real
Estate for acquisition and disposition activity.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;During the quarter ended September&nbsp;30, 2007, the Company repaid the outstanding mortgage
indebtedness on Ft. Myers Beach of approximately $2.9&nbsp;million. During the quarter ended December
31, 2007, the Company repaid a $6.5&nbsp;million mortgage that matured on Park City West RV Resort and
paid down $7.7&nbsp;million of the mortgage debt on Tropical Palms RV Resort. The Tropical Palms RV
Resort mortgage debt balance is currently $12&nbsp;million and matures in December&nbsp;2008.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On March&nbsp;22, 2006, the Company assumed $25.9&nbsp;million in mortgage debt on four of the eleven
Properties related to the acquisition of the Mezzanine Portfolio (see Note 5 in the Notes to
Consolidated Financial Statements contained in this Form 10-K). During the second and third
quarters of 2006, this mortgage debt was defeased. Net proceeds of approximately $10.4&nbsp;million
were used to pay down the lines of credit. In addition, we financed $47.1&nbsp;million of mortgage debt
to acquire the remaining seven Properties in the Mezzanine Portfolio. The Company used the
proceeds to pay down its lines of credit.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On June&nbsp;13, 2006, and on August&nbsp;28, 2006, as a result of meeting certain operational criteria
at its Monte Vista Property and Viewpoint Property, respectively, the Company received an
additional $3.0&nbsp;million and $2.9&nbsp;million, respectively, in mortgage debt proceeds as per the loan
documents. Proceeds from these transactions were used to pay down the Company&#146;s lines of credit.
The terms of these loans remain the same.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On July&nbsp;31, 2006, the Company acquired land for $2.4&nbsp;million subject to a ground lease
previously classified as mortgage debt relating to its Golden Terrace South Property.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>Unsecured Loans</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In September&nbsp;2007, we completed an amendment of our existing unsecured Lines of Credit (&#147;LOC&#148;)
to expand our borrowing capacity from $275&nbsp;million to $420&nbsp;million. Prior to the amendment, the
Company had a $225&nbsp;million LOC and a $50&nbsp;million LOC. The amendment increased the $225&nbsp;million LOC
to $400&nbsp;million and decreased the $50&nbsp;million LOC to $20&nbsp;million. The lines of credit continue to
accrue interest at LIBOR plus a maximum of 1.20% per annum, have a 0.15% facility fee, mature on
June&nbsp;30, 2010, and have a one-year extension option. Our current group of banks have committed up
to $370&nbsp;million on our $420&nbsp;million borrowing capacity. The Company incurred commitment and
arrangement fees of approximately $0.3&nbsp;million to increase its borrowing capacity.
</DIV>


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio -->F-25<!-- /Folio -->
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always">&nbsp;</H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 18pt"><B>Equity LifeStyle Properties, Inc.<BR>
Notes To Consolidated Financial Statements</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>Note 9 &#151; Long-Term Borrowings (continued)</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;As of December&nbsp;31, 2007, the $370&nbsp;million bank commitment had $267&nbsp;million available for
future borrowings. The weighted average interest rate for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2007 was
6.84%.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In 2006, the Company renewed its unsecured debt. The $100&nbsp;million Term Loan and $110&nbsp;million
line of credit were replaced with a $225&nbsp;million line of credit with a four-year maturity and a
one-year extension option, bearing interest at LIBOR plus 1.20% with 0.15% facility fee.
Throughout 2006, the interest rate, including a facility fee, on $100&nbsp;million of the outstanding
balance on the new lines of credit was fixed at 6.18% per annum. In December&nbsp;2006, the Company
fixed $75&nbsp;million of its outstanding lines of credit for one year at 6.38%. The $50&nbsp;million line
of credit was renewed and bears interest at LIBOR plus 1.20% per annum with a 0.20% per annum
facility fee and matures on June&nbsp;29, 2010. The borrowing capacity has since been amended,
discussed above.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>Other Loans</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;During 2007, we borrowed $4.3&nbsp;million to finance our insurance premium payments. As of
December&nbsp;31, 2007, this loan has been paid off.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;During 2006, the Company borrowed $3.6&nbsp;million to finance its insurance premium payments. As
of December&nbsp;31, 2006, $0.3&nbsp;million remained outstanding. This loan was paid off in January&nbsp;2007
and beared interest at 5.30% per annum.
</DIV>

parties or, in some instances, as provided by statute. Non-cancelable long-term leases are in
effect at certain sites within approximately 29 of the Properties. Rental rate increases at these
Properties are primarily a function of increases in the Consumer Price Index, taking into
consideration certain conditions. Additionally, periodic market rate adjustments are made as deemed
appropriate. Future minimum rents are scheduled to be received under non-cancelable tenant leases

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>Note 12 &#151; Transactions with Related Parties</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt"><B>Privileged Access</B>

</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Mr.&nbsp;Joe McAdams, the Company&#146;s President effective January&nbsp;1, 2008, owns 100&nbsp;percent of
Privileged Access. The Company has entered into an employment agreement effective as of January&nbsp;1,
2008 (the &#147;Agreement&#148;) with Mr.&nbsp;McAdams which provides for an initial term of three years, but such
Agreement can be terminated at any time. The Agreement provides for a minimum annual base salary of
$300,000, with the option to receive an annual bonus in an amount up to three times his base
salary. Mr.&nbsp;McAdams is also subject to a non-compete clause and to mitigate potential conflicts of
interest shall have no authority, on behalf of the Company and its affiliates, to enter into any
agreement with any entity controlling, controlled by or affiliated with Privileged Access. Prior
to forming Privileged Access, Mr.&nbsp;McAdams was a member of our Board of Directors from January&nbsp;2004
to October&nbsp;2005. Simultaneous with his appointment as president of Equity Lifestyle Properties,
Inc., Mr.&nbsp;McAdams resigned as Privileged Access&#146;s Chairman, President and CEO. However, he will
remain on its board and retains 100&nbsp;percent ownership of Privileged Access.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Mr.&nbsp;Heneghan, the Company&#146;s CEO, is a member of the board of PATT Holding Company, LLC
(&#147;PATT&#148;), Thousand Trails&#146; parent entity and a subsidiary of Privileged Access, pursuant to the
Company&#146;s rights under its resort Property leases with Privileged Access to represent the Company&#146;s
interests. Mr.&nbsp;Heneghan does not receive compensation in his capacity as a member of such board.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Privileged Access has substantial business relationships with the Company, including the
following:
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt">
<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt">

    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>As of December&nbsp;31, 2007, we are leasing approximately 24,100 sites at 81 resort
Properties (which includes 59 Properties operated by a subsidiary of Privileged Access
known as the &#147;TT Portfolio&#148;) to Privileged Access or its subsidiaries. For the years ended
December&nbsp;31, 2007, 2006 and 2005 we recognized approximately $20.5&nbsp;million, $17.8&nbsp;million,
and $16.0&nbsp;million, respectively, in rent from these leasing arrangements. The lease income
is included in Income from other investments, net in the Company&#146;s Consolidated Statement
of Operations. As of December&nbsp;31, 2007 and 2006, approximately $0.1&nbsp;million and $0.5
million in lease payments, respectively, remain to be received under these leases. During
the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2007 and 2006, the Company reimbursed Privileged Access
approximately $44,000 and $72,000, respectively, for capital improvements. The capital
improvements are assets of the Company.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>

    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>Effective January&nbsp;1, 2008, the leases for these Properties provide for the following
significant terms: a) annual fixed rent of approximately $25.5&nbsp;million b) annual rent
increases at the higher of CPI or a renegotiated amount based upon the fair market value of
the Properties, c) expiration date of January&nbsp;15, 2020, and d) two 5-year extension terms
at the option of Privileged Access. The January&nbsp;1, 2008 lease for the TT Portfolio also
included provisions where the Company paid Privileged Access $1&nbsp;million for entering into
the amended lease. The $1&nbsp;million payment will be amortized on a pro-rata basis over the
remaining term of the lease as an offset to the annual lease payments. Additionally, the Company also agreed to reimburse Privileged Access
up to $5&nbsp;million for the cost of any</TD>
</TR>

would not make its lease payment on the TT Portfolio as a result of the subordination is

Company&#146;s Consolidated Statement of Operations. As of December&nbsp;31, 2007 and 2006,

date of June&nbsp;30, 2008.</TD>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>Note 13 &#151; Stock Option Plan and Stock Grants</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">The Company&#146;s Stock Option and Stock Award Plan (the &#147;Plan&#148;) was adopted in December&nbsp;1992 and
amended and restated from time to time, most recently effective March&nbsp;23, 2001. Pursuant to the
Plan, officers, directors, employees and consultants of the Company are offered the opportunity (i)
to acquire shares of common stock through the grant of stock options (&#147;Options&#148;), including
non-qualified stock options and, for key employees, incentive stock options within the meaning of
Section&nbsp;422 of the Internal Revenue Code; and (ii)&nbsp;to be awarded shares of common stock
(&#147;Restricted Stock Grants&#148;), subject to conditions and restrictions determined by the Compensation,
Nominating, and Corporate Governance Committee of the Company&#146;s Board of Directors (the
&#147;Compensation Committee&#148;). The Compensation Committee will determine the vesting schedule, if any,
of each Option and the term, which term shall not exceed ten years from the date of grant. As to
the Options that have been granted through December&nbsp;31, 2007 to officers, employees and
consultants, generally, one-third are exercisable one year after the initial grant, one-third are
exercisable two years following the date such Options were granted and the remaining one-third are
exercisable three years following the date such Options were granted. Stock Options are awarded at
the New York Stock Exchange closing price of the Company&#146;s common stock on the grant date. A
maximum of
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio -->F-29<!-- /Folio -->
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always">&nbsp;</H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: 'Times New Roman',Times,serif">

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 18pt"><B>Equity LifeStyle Properties, Inc.<BR>
Notes To Consolidated Financial Statements</B>
</DIV>



<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>Note 13 &#151; Stock Option Plan and Stock Grants (continued)</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">6,000,000 shares of common stock are available for grant under the Plan and no more than 250,000
shares may be subject to
grants to any one individual in any calendar year.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Grants under the Plan are made by the Compensation Committee, which determines the individuals
eligible to receive awards, the types of awards, and the terms, conditions and restrictions
applicable to any award. In addition, the terms of two specific types
of awards are contemplated under the Plan:
</DIV>


<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt">
<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt">

<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="2%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="3%" nowrap align="left"><B>&#149;</B></TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>The first type of award is a grant of Options or Restricted Stock Grants of common stock
made to each member of the Board at the meeting held immediately after each annual meeting
of the Company&#146;s stockholders. Generally, if the director elects to receive Options, the
grant will cover 10,000 shares of common stock at an exercise price equal to the fair
market value on the date of grant. If the director elects to receive a Restricted Stock
Grant of common stock, he or she will receive an award of 2,000 shares of common stock.
Exercisability or vesting with respect to either type of award will be one-third of the
award after six months, two-thirds of the award after one year, and the full award after
two years.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR><TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="2%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="3%" nowrap align="left"><B>&#149;</B></TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>The second type of award is a grant of common stock in lieu of 50% of their bonus
otherwise payable to individuals with a title of Vice President or above. A recipient can
request that the Compensation Committee pay a greater or lesser portion of the bonus in
shares of common stock.</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company adopted SFAS 123(R) on July&nbsp;1, 2005, which replaced SFAS 123. Since the Company
had chosen to use the modified-prospective method for recognizing stock-based compensation and uses
the Black-Scholes-Merton Model for valuing the options, the result of the adoption had no material
impact of the Company&#146;s results of operations or financial position.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Restricted Stock Grants</I>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In 2006, the Company awarded Restricted Stock Grants for 147,500 shares of common stock to
certain members of senior management of the Company. These Restricted Stock Grants vest over three
years. The fair market value of these Restricted Stock Grants was approximately $8.1&nbsp;million as of
the date of grant and is recorded as compensation expense and paid in capital over the three year
vesting period.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In 2004, the Company awarded Restricted Stock Grants for 135,000 shares of common stock to
certain members of senior management of the Company. These Restricted Stock Grants vest over three
years, but may be restricted for a period of up to ten years depending upon certain performance
benchmarks. The fair market value of these Restricted Stock Grants was approximately $5.0&nbsp;million
as of the date of grant and is recorded as compensation expense and paid in capital over the three
year vesting period.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In 2007, 2006 and 2005, the Company awarded Restricted Stock Grants for 18,000, 23,000 and
22,500 shares of common stock, respectively, to directors with a fair market value of approximately
$984,000, $1,050,000 and $812,000 in 2007, 2006 and 2005, respectively.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company recognized compensation expense of approximately $3.7&nbsp;million, $2.8&nbsp;million and
$2.8&nbsp;million related to Restricted Stock Grants in 2007, 2006 and 2005, respectively.
</DIV>

</DIV>

    <TD align="right" valign="top" style="border-top: 3px double #000000">&nbsp;</TD>

<!-- End Table Body -->
</TABLE>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;As of December&nbsp;31, 2007, 2006 and 2005, 1,283,842 shares, 1,465,642 shares and 1,775,975
shares remained available for grant, respectively; of these 650,525 shares, 668,525 shares and
839,025 shares, respectively, remained available for Restricted Stock Grants.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio -->F-31<!-- /Folio -->
</DIV>
